elements.content: A new one-dimensional double chain photoluminescent Hg­(II) coordination polymer (CP), {[Hg­(L)2]·(ClO4)2} n (1), was synthesized using a benzimidazole-appended tripodal tridentate ligand, 1,3,5-tris­(benzimidazolylmethyl)­benzene (L). The dynamic and flexible framework of 1 allows it to be entitled as first Hg­(II)-based CP belonging to the rare category of CPs that exhibit multistimuli-responsive photoluminescence sensing properties and called as “smart” material. The sensitivity of this material via luminescence quenching method showing “turn off” behavior to a range of stimuli, including anions, solvents, and nitroaromatic compounds (NACs), offers more fine-grained control over its properties. 1 can easily adjust its channel dimensions to encapsulate different guest anions forming complete/partial anion-exchanged materials 1A–1B/1C–1E using NO3 –, BF4 –, OTf–, OTs–, and PF6 – anions, respectively. Reversible (1A and 1B) and irreversible (1C–1E) anion exchange behaviors were observed for the complete and partial anion-exchanged products, respectively. The noteworthy feature of the anion-exchanged compounds is their anion-triggered luminescent behavior depending on different properties of anions.The excellent emission in water and high hydrolytic stability of 1 allows its use for rapid and efficient fluorescence-based detections of NACs in aquatic system. The uncoordinated pendant benzimidazole moiety in 1 serves as Lewis basic recognition site for trinitrophenol (TNP) detection, and along with electron- and energy-transfer mechanisms, 1 forms a luminescent probe for detection of TNP with low detection limits (0.55 ppm), exhibiting excellent photostability and recyclability. 1 also represents the first reported Hg­(II)-based sensory CP material that can discriminate nitrophenol and nitroaniline isomers through fluorescence sensing.

Reversible (1A and 1B) and irreversible (1C-1E) anion exchange behaviors were observed for the complete and partial anion-exchanged products, respectively. The noteworthy feature of the anion-exchanged compounds is their anion-triggered luminescent behavior depending on different properties of anions.The excellent emission in water and high hydrolytic stability of 1 allows its use for rapid and efficient fluorescence-based detections of NACs in aquatic system. elements.content: A dynamic and flexible photoluminescent cationic coordination polymer {[Hg­(L)2]·(ClO4)2} n (1) [L = 1,3,5-tris­(benzimidazolylmethyl)­benzene] with excellent hydrolytic stability is reported. 1 represents the first example of Hg­(II)-based fluorescent CP with differential multistimuli-responsive behavior for a range of stimuli (anions, solvent, and nitro aromatic compounds) and entitled as “smart” sensor material showing multifunctional behavior for anion-triggered luminescence, 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (0.55 ppm) detection, and discriminate solvent, nitrophenol, and nitroaniline isomers.

elements.content: Dynamic coordination polymers (CPs) on account of structural flexibility and tunable properties have emerged as an exciting class of multistimuli-responsive materials, which can change one or more of their properties in response to an external stimulus, such as pH, light, or presence of a chemical species. Such materials can be ascribed as “smart” host materials and can be multifunctional by triggering host–guest interactions via selective molecular recognition, guest/anion exchange, separation, and sensing. However, the development of dual- or multiple-stimuli responsive CPs remains in an early stage, and examples are relatively rare compared with those of single-stimuli responsive systems. In recent years, luminescent CPs have received immense interest on account of their easy synthesis, unique and functional properties, high thermal/chemical stability, host–guest interaction, diversity in size, shape, dimensionality, crystalline nature, good recyclability, pre/postsynthetic functionalizability, and responsiveness. Fluorescent CPs responding to changes in external stimuli are of great interest, as stimuli-responsive fluorescent systems play an important role in the fields of sensors, security papers, optoelectronic switches, and information storage.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Dynamic coordination polymers (CPs) on account of structural flexibility and tunable properties have emerged as an exciting class of multistimuli-responsive materials, which can change one or more of their properties in response to an external stimulus, such as pH, light, or presence of a chemical species. Such materials can be ascribed as "smart" host materials and can be multifunctional by triggering host-guest interactions via selective molecular recognition, guest/anion exchange, separation, and sensing. However, the development of dual- or multiple-stimuli responsive CPs remains in an early stage, and examples are relatively rare compared with those of single-stimuli responsive systems. In recent years, luminescent CPs have received immense interest on account of their easy synthesis, unique and functional properties, high thermal/chemical stability, host-guest interaction, diversity in size, shape, dimensionality, crystalline nature, good recyclability, pre/postsynthetic functionalizability, and responsiveness. Fluorescent CPs responding to changes in external stimuli are of great interest, as stimuli-responsive fluorescent systems play an important role in the fields of sensors, security papers, optoelectronic switches, and information storage.

elements.content: Luminescent cationic CP framework made of neutral flexible N-donor ligands and metal ions consists of anions occupied in the framework void (via weak hydrogen bonding or anion-π interactions) or weakly coordinated to the metal centers. When these anions are exchanged with other anions, which act as chemical stimuli, of different shape, size, and coordinating nature, the dynamic luminescent frameworks lead to changes in structure and physical properties. Such materials can be conceived as potential candidates for anion sensing, encapsulation/separation or recognition by inducing a response in terms of fluorescence and can be used to monitor the presence of an anionic guest.
elements.clean_text: Luminescent cationic CP framework made of neutral flexible N-donor ligands and metal ions consists of anions occupied in the framework void (via weak hydrogen bonding or anion-π interactions) or weakly coordinated to the metal centers. When these anions are exchanged with other anions, which act as chemical stimuli, of different shape, size, and coordinating nature, the dynamic luminescent frameworks lead to changes in structure and physical properties. Such materials can be conceived as potential candidates for anion sensing, encapsulation/separation or recognition by inducing a response in terms of fluorescence and can be used to monitor the presence of an anionic guest.

elements.content: In addition to anion sensing, such dynamic luminescent cationic CP frameworks have also emerged as efficient sensors for the detection of energetic nitroaromatic compounds (NACs). The NACs being highly explosive in nature have also been classified as one of the major classes of pollutants in groundwater, soil, and other security applications due to their high toxicity and the detriment caused to human health by exposing to them directly or indirectly. So, convenient and efficient technology for detecting NACs in the environment has received much attention and involves traditional instrumental techniques that usually require very expensive instruments, difficult accessibility, and inconvenient processes. Fluorescent CPs have gained interest in recent years for the efficient detection of NACs in aqueous systems, due to their high sensitivity, selective nature with a fast-response time for trace and discriminative detection, easy operation, and low-cost detection systems for in-field use.

elements.content: The flexible CPs-based fluorescent sensors containing specific functional sites (unsaturated metal centers, nonbonded ligand functional site, and tunable pore sizes) that can interact with the analyte via specific recognition selectively and efficiently, enables the reversible uptake/release of substrates to increase regeneration and recycling. The presence of suitable fluorophore units such as an aromatic ring with a nonbonded functional site in the framework (receptor unit) can generate a distinct emission upon selective recognition of analytes. Once the analyte is recognized by the receptor, the fluorescence responses can be observed in the form of quenching (turn off) or enhancement (turn on) in the emission intensity due to charge transfer, energy transfer, or electron donor–acceptor transfer mechanisms.

The presence of suitable fluorophore units such as an aromatic ring with a nonbonded functional site in the framework (receptor unit) can generate a distinct emission upon selective recognition of analytes. Once the analyte is recognized by the receptor, the fluorescence responses can be observed in the form of quenching (turn off) or enhancement (turn on) in the emission intensity due to charge transfer, energy transfer, or electron donor-acceptor transfer mechanisms.

elements.content: Within CPs, those containing d10 metal ions are widely explored for their high structural diversity and versatility, rich photophysical behavior, interesting electrical properties, and high luminance efficiency. On the contrary, in spite of attractive properties of mercury­(II) compounds in thermometers, manometers, paper industry, paints, cosmetics, preservatives, energy-efficient fluorescent light bulbs and batteries, the CPs reported with Hg­(II) are infrequent as compared to Zn­(II) and Cd­(II). To the best of our knowledge, so far no Hg­(II)-based luminescent CPs have been exploited as multistimuli-responsive fluorescence-based sensor showing stimuli-triggered luminescent behavior via anion exchange and detections of NACs and solvents.

To the best of our knowledge, so far no Hg(II)-based luminescent CPs have been exploited as multistimuli-responsive fluorescence-based sensor showing stimuli-triggered luminescent behavior via anion exchange and detections of NACs and solvents.

elements.content: Herein, we report a novel photoluminescent Hg­(II)-based CP, {[Hg­(L)2]·(ClO4)2} n (1), where L stands for the benzimidazole-appended tripodal tridentate ligand, 1,3,5-tris­(benzimidazolylmethyl)­benzene (). The CP framework showed dynamic and flexible nature by virtue of facile anion exchange behaviors forming complete/partial anion-exchanged products depending upon the incoming anion. The complete anion-exchange products 1A and 1B were obtained by using NO3 – and BF4 – anions, respectively. On the contrary, with OTf–, OTs–, and PF6 – anions a partial anion exchange was observed forming products 1C, 1D, and 1E, respectively. In addition, anion-exchanged products 1A and 1B could be reverted to 1 by adding ClO4 – anions. However, products 1C, 1D, and 1E remained unchanged upon addition of ClO4 – anions. Interestingly, among the anions employed for anion-exchange study, the framework of 1 showed more affinity toward small anions than larger ones, and the noteworthy feature of the anion exchanged compounds is their anion-triggered luminescent behavior. In addition, 1 shows distinct solvent-dependent fluorescence and high hydrolytic stability leading to a rapid and efficient fluorescence-based detection of NACs. Moreover, to the best of our knowledge, 1 also represents the first reported Hg­(II)-based sensory CP material that can discriminate nitrophenol and nitroaniline isomers through fluorescence sensing. Henceforth, incorporating all the above features into a single species makes CP 1 the very first Hg­(II)-based “smart” material with multiple functionality that shows multiresponsive fluorescence sensing behavior for anions, solvents, and NACs.

The complete anion-exchange products 1A and 1B were obtained by using NO3 - and BF4 - anions, respectively. elements.content: Reagent-grade 1,3,5-tris­(bromomethyl)­benzene, NaH (60% dispersion), NaClO4, NaBF4, sodium trifluoromethanesulfonate (NaOTf), sodium p-toluenesulfonate (NaOTs), 2-nitrophenol, 3-nitrophenol, 4-nitrophenol, 4-nitroaniline, 4′-nitroacetophenone, 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene, 1-chloro-2,4-dinitrobenzene, 2-amino-4-nitrophenol, and 2-amino-5-nitrophenol were acquired from Sigma-Aldrich. Benzimidazole and 2-nitroaniline were procured from Spectrochem and Loba Chemie, respectively. Hg­(ClO4)2·3H2O, NaNO3, KPF6, 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (picric acid, TNP), and 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP) were obtained from Alfa Aesar. All the chemicals and solvents were used as received without further purification. Infrared spectra were obtained (KBr disk, 400–4000 cm–1) using ABB MB3000 Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer. The crystal structures were obtained using a Bruker AXS Kappa Apex II CCD diffractometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using Bruker D8 Advanced instrument with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.540 598 Å) and scan rate of 3° min–1 at 293 K. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed in N2 atmosphere on TGA Q500 V20.10 Build 36 (at a heating rate of 10 °C/min). NMR spectral data were obtained from a Bruker FT NMR spectrometer (500 MHz for 1H) in deuterated dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO-d 6). Microanalyses for the compounds were obtained using Elementar vario microcube. Solid-state photoexcitation and emission spectra were recorded at room temperature using a UV–vis–NIR spectrophotometer (NIR = near-infrared; Varian model Cary 5000) and Horiba-Jobin-Yvon Fluoro MaxR-4 spectrofluorometer, respectively. Solution-state emission spectra were recorded on Jasco FP-6300 spectrofluorometer at room temperature. The energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) data were obtained using Philips XL-30 SEM with EDAX system. ChemBioDrawUltra 11.0, Diamond (version 4.0) and Mercury (version 3.6) were used to view and generate graphics.

Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

Reagent-grade 1,3,5-tris(bromomethyl)benzene, NaH (60% dispersion), NaClO4, NaBF4, sodium trifluoromethanesulfonate (NaOTf), sodium p-toluenesulfonate (NaOTs), 2-nitrophenol, 3-nitrophenol, 4-nitrophenol, 4-nitroaniline, 4'-nitroacetophenone, 1-chloro-4-nitrobenzene, 1-chloro-2,4-dinitrobenzene, 2-amino-4-nitrophenol, and 2-amino-5-nitrophenol were acquired from Sigma-Aldrich. Benzimidazole and 2-nitroaniline were procured from Spectrochem and Loba Chemie, respectively. Hg(ClO4)2⋅3H2O, NaNO3, KPF6, 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (picric acid, TNP), and 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP) were obtained from Alfa Aesar. All the chemicals and solvents were used as received without further purification. Infrared spectra were obtained (KBr disk, 400-4000 cm-1) using ABB MB3000 Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer. The crystal structures were obtained using a Bruker AXS Kappa Apex II CCD diffractometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using Bruker D8 Advanced instrument with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.540598 Å) and scan rate of 3° min-1 at 293 K. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed in N2 atmosphere on TGA Q500 V20.10 Build 36 (at a heating rate of 10 °C/min). NMR spectral data were obtained from a Bruker FT NMR spectrometer (500 MHz for 1H) in deuterated dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO-d 6). Microanalyses for the compounds were obtained using Elementar vario microcube. Solid-state photoexcitation and emission spectra were recorded at room temperature using a UV-vis-NIR spectrophotometer (NIR = near-infrared; Varian model Cary 5000) and Horiba-Jobin-Yvon Fluoro MaxR-4 spectrofluorometer, respectively. Solution-state emission spectra were recorded on Jasco FP-6300 spectrofluorometer at room temperature. The energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) data were obtained using Philips XL-30 SEM with EDAX system. ChemBioDrawUltra 11.0, Diamond (version 4.0) and Mercury (version 3.6) were used to view and generate graphics.

elements.content: Well-ground powder of 1 (20 mg) was suspended in a 5 mL aqueous solution of NaX/KPF6 (X = NO3 –, BF4 –, OTf–, OTs–) (40 mg) and was stirred for 3 d at room temperature to allow anion exchange. The solid was separated from aqueous solution by centrifuging, washed with water several times, and dried in vacuum to give white powder. This procedure was repeated twice to afford anion-exchanged products.
elements.clean_text:
Anion Exchange Reaction

Well-ground powder of 1 (20 mg) was suspended in a 5 mL aqueous solution of NaX/KPF6 (X = NO3 -, BF4 -, OTf-, OTs-) (40 mg) and was stirred for 3 d at room temperature to allow anion exchange. The solid was separated from aqueous solution by centrifuging, washed with water several times, and dried in vacuum to give white powder. This procedure was repeated twice to afford anion-exchanged products.

Powder XRD data were also recorded for 1 soaked in water for 1 and 3 d and after heating at 80 and 100 °C for 24 h.

elements.content: Finely grounded sample of 1 (0.5 mg) was well-dispersed in different solvents (10 mL) using ultrasonic agitation for 20 min followed by aging for 1 d. The stable homogeneous suspensions so obtained were used to measure fluorescence emission spectra.
elements.clean_text:
Effect of Solvents

Finely grounded sample of 1 (0.5 mg) was well-dispersed in different solvents (10 mL) using ultrasonic agitation for 20 min followed by aging for 1 d. The stable homogeneous suspensions so obtained were used to measure fluorescence emission spectra.

elements.content: To prepare the stock solution, 1 was ground in powder and well-dispersed in deionized H2O (5 mL) using ultrasonic agitation for 60 min. It was then diluted to 100 mL and aged for 1 d to form a stable homogeneous suspension. Different NAC solutions (10 mM) were prepared using N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 5 mL) for luminescence detection. The quenching experiments were performed by the incremental addition of NACs (0 to 200 μM) to the aforementioned H2O suspension. To maintain the homogeneity, sample was shaken well before each run after the addition of NACs.
elements.clean_text:
NACs Sensing Experiments

To prepare the stock solution, 1 was ground in powder and well-dispersed in deionized H2O (5 mL) using ultrasonic agitation for 60 min. It was then diluted to 100 mL and aged for 1 d to form a stable homogeneous suspension. Different NAC solutions (10 mM) were prepared using N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 5 mL) for luminescence detection. The quenching experiments were performed by the incremental addition of NACs (0 to 200 μM) to the aforementioned H2O suspension. To maintain the homogeneity, sample was shaken well before each run after the addition of NACs.

elements.content: A sample of 1 (5 mg) was ground in powder and well-dispersed in deionized H2O (5 mL) using ultrasonic agitation for 60 min. Different NAC solutions (10 mM) in DMF (5 mL) were prepared, and 40 μM was added to suspension of 1 followed by centrifuging the dispersed solution and washing several times with DMF until the centrifugate became colorless and subsequently analyzed by powder XRD.
elements.clean_text:
Stability Experiments of 1 in Different NACs

A sample of 1 (5 mg) was ground in powder and well-dispersed in deionized H2O (5 mL) using ultrasonic agitation for 60 min. Different NAC solutions (10 mM) in DMF (5 mL) were prepared, and 40 μM was added to suspension of 1 followed by centrifuging the dispersed solution and washing several times with DMF until the centrifugate became colorless and subsequently analyzed by powder XRD.

elements.content: The CPs constructed with flexible linkers show dynamic and flexible behaviors by tuning their cavity size according to the guest molecules for host–guest interactions. As compared to rigid linkers, the flexible linkers may adapt various conformations for satisfying different geometric requirements of the metal ions. Flexible tripodal ligands with arene core and N-donors are among the most useful organic building blocks for the construction of coordination frameworks with various conformations and coordination modes.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Strategy

The CPs constructed with flexible linkers show dynamic and flexible behaviors by tuning their cavity size according to the guest molecules for host-guest interactions. As compared to rigid linkers, the flexible linkers may adapt various conformations for satisfying different geometric requirements of the metal ions. Flexible tripodal ligands with arene core and N-donors are among the most useful organic building blocks for the construction of coordination frameworks with various conformations and coordination modes.

elements.content: Depending on the position of three benzimidazole groups, relative to the central benzene ring plane, the ligand L can adapt three different conformations in its complexes (): (a) W-form, in which three imidazole groups are all located in the same side of the central benzene ring plane, (b) Y-form, where three benzimidazole groups are distributed on the two sides of the central benzene ring plane, and (c) T-form, where two of three benzimidazole groups are located above and below the central benzene ring plane, while the third benzimidazole ring is close to the benzene ring plane. A related ligand relevant to this work, 1,3,5-tris­(benzimidazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene, L′, also adopts comparable conformations in its complexes.

A related ligand relevant to this work, 1,3,5-tris(benzimidazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene, L', also adopts comparable conformations in its complexes.

elements.content: Sun and co-workers reported a discrete binuclear Hg­(II) complex, [Hg2(Br)4(L′)2] (1′), which was prepared via combination of equimolar ratios of HgBr2 and tripodal ligand L′. Each Hg­(II) center lies in a tetrahedral coordination geometry and is coordinated by two bromide ions and two benzimidazole units belonging to different L′ units. Two of the benzimidazole arms of each ligand moiety were used for coordination in a nonchelating manner leaving one arm free of coordination (a). The complex 1′ possesses a narrow cavity due to intramolecular π–π stacking between two benzimidazole units located in diagonally opposite positions; also, methyl units added steric hindrance around the macrocyclic cavity.

The complex 1' possesses a narrow cavity due to intramolecular π-π stacking between two benzimidazole units located in diagonally opposite positions; also, methyl units added steric hindrance around the macrocyclic cavity.

elements.content: We were interested in the construction of a CP consisting of cavities for anion binding. In addition, the incorporation of nonbonded functional sites was considered in the designed framework as recognition sites for selective binding of analytes. Construction of extended coordination network with nonbonded functionalities was targeted via complexation of a Hg­(II) salt having weakly coordinating counteranion with a benzimidazole-appended tripodal tridentate ligand. Further, the methyl groups were avoided in the sterically less-hindered ligand L. Complexation of Hg­(ClO4)2·3H2O with ligand L in a 1:2 ratio in DMSO led to the formation of 1 (b and ) as white crystals, which were found to be stable in air and insoluble in water and common organic solvents. 1 was analyzed through IR, elemental analysis, 1H NMR (sparingly soluble in DMSO), and single-crystal X-ray diffraction methods. The IR spectral data of 1 show features attributable to the C–H stretching vibration of imidazolyl group at 3118 cm–1 and the C–N band at 1518 cm–1. The characteristic stretching vibration of ClO4 – anion in 1 is located at 1091 (asymmetric stretch) and 620 (asymmetric bend) cm–1. The structure of 1 was analyzed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction study before the study of its properties was ventured.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/n (Table S1), with Hg­(II) ion located in a distorted square-planar environment and coordinated by four benzimidazole N atoms from four L units (a). The asymmetric unit consists of one Hg­(II) ion (half occupancy), one L ligand, and one perchlorate counteranion. The ClO4 – anions exhibit short contact [2.815(4) Å] with Hg­(II) ion from one of the O atoms (O4) (Figure S1). Two adjacent metal centers are connected by two L ligands forming a bimetallic 24-membered macrocyclic loop in which the two Hg­(II) units are separated by a distance of 9.49(8) Å. The macrocycles are further extended to furnish a one-dimensional (1D) double chain type CP 1 (a).
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Structure of {[Hg(L)2]⋅(ClO4)2}n (1)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/n (Table S1), with Hg(II) ion located in a distorted square-planar environment and coordinated by four benzimidazole N atoms from four L units (a). The asymmetric unit consists of one Hg(II) ion (half occupancy), one L ligand, and one perchlorate counteranion. The ClO4 - anions exhibit short contact [2.815(4) Å] with Hg(II) ion from one of the O atoms (O4) (Figure S1). Two adjacent metal centers are connected by two L ligands forming a bimetallic 24-membered macrocyclic loop in which the two Hg(II) units are separated by a distance of 9.49(8) Å. The macrocycles are further extended to furnish a one-dimensional (1D) double chain type CP 1 (a).

elements.content: In 1, similar to the Hg­(II)-based macrocyclic binuclear structure with bromide counteranion reported by Sun and co-workers, the third benzimidazole ring of L is uncoordinated behaving as a pendant and is oriented upside-down on opposite sides of each macrocycle running through the entire double chain. Because of the flexible behavior of L the benzimidazole rings adopt Y-form (), and the dihedral angle between coordinated benzimidazole groups is 31.45(4)°, while for uncoordinated and coordinated ones they are 69.92(2)° [N5] and 38.70(3)° [N4]. The average Hg–N distances are 2.380(6) Å, which are well-within the reported values in the literature (Table S2).

elements.content: The individual 1D double chains in 1 are stabilized via supramolecular interactions leading to a two-dimensional (2D) supramolecular arrangement (b and S2), facilitated by ClO4 – anions that exhibit H-bonding (Figure S3). The additional stability to independent chains is provided through interchain π–π interactions between two pendants as well as pendant and coordinated benzimidazole rings having an interplanar distance of 0.12° and 4.59°, respectively (Figure S4).

elements.content: To confirm the sample purity, powder XRD was performed for 1, which showed correlation between the simulated and experimental spectra, thereby confirming the phase purity of 1 at room temperature (Figure S5). The thermal stability of the same was studied using TGA, and the TGA profile indicated that it is thermally stable up to 245 °C, thereafter showing a sudden weight loss, leaving a residual weight of 23% (Figure S6).
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction and Thermogravimetric Analysis

To confirm the sample purity, powder XRD was performed for 1, which showed correlation between the simulated and experimental spectra, thereby confirming the phase purity of 1 at room temperature (Figure S5). The thermal stability of the same was studied using TGA, and the TGA profile indicated that it is thermally stable up to 245 °C, thereafter showing a sudden weight loss, leaving a residual weight of 23% (Figure S6).

elements.content: CPs with luminescent organic chromophores coordinated to d10 transition metals are found to exhibit excellent photoluminescence properties and can be promising candidates for potential photoactive materials and find application as sensors, optoelectronic switches, and information storage devices. Motivated by the intense luminescence of L in solid state, with emission maxima at 383 nm (λex 310 nm) due to the π*−π transition, the photoluminescence property of CP 1 with Hg­(II) metal ion was investigated at room temperature (). CP 1 is red-shifted from the ligand and exhibits intense emission at 430 nm (λex 330 nm), which can be attributed to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) transition. The increased emission in CP 1 may be caused due to increased rigidity of the ligand upon formation of CP, which minimizes both the nonradiative decay rate as well as the intramolecular/intermoleculear interactions among the organic linkers leading to reduction of possible energy transfer. The presence of ClO4 – anions may also facilitate the decrease of the loss of energy through nonradiative decay thereby increasing fluorescence intensity. In general, Hg­(II)-based CPs are found to show quenching of luminescence intensity due to heavy atom effect; however, on the contrary, Huang and co-workers reported Hg­(II) halide/pseudohalide bipyridine (2,2′- or 4,4′-bipyridine) complexes/CPs that showed intense luminescence. Interestingly, CP 1 shows a threefold enhancement in luminescence, as compared to L, which makes it suitable to be employed as Hg­(II)-based luminescent sensor material.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence

CPs with luminescent organic chromophores coordinated to d10 transition metals are found to exhibit excellent photoluminescence properties and can be promising candidates for potential photoactive materials and find application as sensors, optoelectronic switches, and information storage devices. Motivated by the intense luminescence of L in solid state, with emission maxima at 383 nm (λex 310 nm) due to the π*-π transition, the photoluminescence property of CP 1 with Hg(II) metal ion was investigated at room temperature (). CP 1 is red-shifted from the ligand and exhibits intense emission at 430 nm (λex 330 nm), which can be attributed to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) transition. The increased emission in CP 1 may be caused due to increased rigidity of the ligand upon formation of CP, which minimizes both the nonradiative decay rate as well as the intramolecular/intermoleculear interactions among the organic linkers leading to reduction of possible energy transfer. The presence of ClO4 - anions may also facilitate the decrease of the loss of energy through nonradiative decay thereby increasing fluorescence intensity. In general, Hg(II)-based CPs are found to show quenching of luminescence intensity due to heavy atom effect; however, on the contrary, Huang and co-workers reported Hg(II) halide/pseudohalide bipyridine (2,2'- or 4,4'-bipyridine) complexes/CPs that showed intense luminescence. Interestingly, CP 1 shows a threefold enhancement in luminescence, as compared to L, which makes it suitable to be employed as Hg(II)-based luminescent sensor material.

elements.content: Luminescent flexible N-donor ligands upon coordination to a d10 metal ion usually form a luminescent dynamic cationic framework, and this luminescent behavior can be tuned by exchange of already present anions with other anions. The anion-switchable fluorescence (turn off/on) of such frameworks can serve as potential chemical sensors and anion receptors for the construction of new luminescent materials.
elements.clean_text:
Anion Exchange

Luminescent flexible N-donor ligands upon coordination to a d10 metal ion usually form a luminescent dynamic cationic framework, and this luminescent behavior can be tuned by exchange of already present anions with other anions. The anion-switchable fluorescence (turn off/on) of such frameworks can serve as potential chemical sensors and anion receptors for the construction of new luminescent materials.

elements.content: As revealed by crystal structure of 1, the ClO4 – anions are held via weak electrostatic and H-bonding interactions and can be probed for possible anion-exchange reactions. In an initial test for anion exchange, finely ground powder of 1 was soaked in an aqueous solution of NaX/KPF6 (X = NO3 –, BF4 –, OTf–, OTs–), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature to allow anion exchange. The occurrence of anion exchange was corroborated by comparison of the characterization data (IR spectra, elemental analysis, EDX, and powder XRD) of anion-exchanged products with those of the corresponding CP 1 (). In addition, the anion-exchanged products (1A–1E) displayed different anion-dependent luminescent behavior as compared to 1, thereby confirming the occurrence of anion exchange.
elements.clean_text: As revealed by crystal structure of 1, the ClO4 - anions are held via weak electrostatic and H-bonding interactions and can be probed for possible anion-exchange reactions. In an initial test for anion exchange, finely ground powder of 1 was soaked in an aqueous solution of NaX/KPF6 (X = NO3 -, BF4 -, OTf-, OTs-), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature to allow anion exchange. The occurrence of anion exchange was corroborated by comparison of the characterization data (IR spectra, elemental analysis, EDX, and powder XRD) of anion-exchanged products with those of the corresponding CP 1 (). In addition, the anion-exchanged products (1A-1E) displayed different anion-dependent luminescent behavior as compared to 1, thereby confirming the occurrence of anion exchange.

elements.clean_text: 2  Anion Exchange Reactions in 1

elements.content: The anion-exchange reaction of 1 with NaNO3 and NaBF4 forms subsequent products 1A and 1B, respectively, which show almost disappearance of intense peaks (1091 and 620 cm–1) originating from ClO4 – anion, and new bands corresponding to NO3 – (1384 cm–1) and BF4 – (1072 cm–1) anions appear in the spectrum (a). It indicates that the ClO4 – anions in the voids of 1 were exchanged almost completely by NO3 – (1A) and BF4 – (1B) anions. However, anion exchange with NaOTf, NaOTs, and KPF6 formed products 1C, 1D, and 1E, respectively, which shows new bands corresponding to OTf– (1267 cm–1), OTs– (1200 cm–1), and PF6 – (845 and 559 cm–1) anions, along with the already present peaks (1091 and 620 cm–1) of ClO4 – anion (b). Interestingly, 1C–1E shows coexistence of anions due to partial anion exchange of the already present ClO4 – anions with the new incoming anions (OTf–, OTs–, and PF6 –). In the IR spectra of 1A–1E other peaks remained unchanged, which implies that the framework remained intact after the exchange process. The proposed anion exchange phenomena were also supported by EDX spectra of the original complex 1 and the anion-exchanged samples 1A–1E (Figures S10–S15). The EDX peaks correspond to the presence/absence of relevant elements in the samples in line with the proposal of complete or partial anion exchange.

It indicates that the ClO4 - anions in the voids of 1 were exchanged almost completely by NO3 - (1A) and BF4 - (1B) anions. However, anion exchange with NaOTf, NaOTs, and KPF6 formed products 1C, 1D, and 1E, respectively, which shows new bands corresponding to OTf- (1267 cm-1), OTs- (1200 cm-1), and PF6 - (845 and 559 cm-1) anions, along with the already present peaks (1091 and 620 cm-1) of ClO4 - anion (b). elements.content: To allow reverse anion exchange, the solids 1A–1E were suspended in aqueous solution of NaClO4 with constant stirring. In case of 1A and 1B the bands corresponding to ClO4 – anion were restored (1091 and 620 cm–1), while the bands of NO3 – (1384 cm–1) and BF4 – (1072 cm–1), respectively, disappeared suggesting the reversible nature of anion-exchange reactions by restoring 1 (Figure S7). The reversible anion exchange with partially anion exchanged products 1C–1E proved to be unsuccessful.

In case of 1A and 1B the bands corresponding to ClO4 - anion were restored (1091 and 620 cm-1), while the bands of NO3 - (1384 cm-1) and BF4 - (1072 cm-1), respectively, disappeared suggesting the reversible nature of anion-exchange reactions by restoring 1 (Figure S7). elements.content: The selective formation of 1A–1E and 1 (after reversible anion exchange) was further confirmed by powder XRD revealing a single-crystalline phase in the final product (Figures S8 and S9). The powder XRD patterns of the anion-exchanged products (1A–1E) are quite different for different types of anions, which arises due to the different coordinating tendencies, shapes, and sizes of the anions and also their different electrostatic/π–π interactions and hydrogen-bonding abilities, thus showing the highly flexible nature of the framework. Consequently, as the anion exchange of 1 occurred through a purely solid-state mechanism, the selectivity of anion exchange might be attributed to the size of the ingoing anions, which is related to the size of the pore window (ca. 7.2 × 4.14 Å2) in 1. On the one hand, the smaller anions (NO3 – and BF4 –) would enter the crystalline lattice of 1 more readily and can easily replace the weakly held ClO4 – anions from the parent framework leading to complete anion exchange and may induce structural changes after the exchange process. On the other hand, bigger anions may/may not (OTf–, OTs– and PF6 –) fit into the framework leading to partial anion exchange and fewer structural changes as compared to smaller anions. Thus, in present scenario the anions are playing the role of external chemical stimuli for the structural changes in the course of exchange process.

elements.content: CP 1 can adjust its framework to encapsulate different guest anions because of its dynamic nature. Anion-exchanged materials 1A–1E showed interesting anion-dependent luminescent behavior. The solid-state emission spectra of powdered samples of all anion-exchanged compounds were measured at room temperature (Figure S16). Compounds 1A–E displayed broad bands upon excitation at 330 nm with intensity maxima at 421, 422, 388, 431, and 378 nm, respectively. The emission intensity of 1 in all anion-exchanged compounds showed a decrease in luminescence intensity via “turn-off” mechanism, and the percentage of quenching follows the order: 1E (75%) > 1C (63%) > 1A (60%) > 1B (45%) > 1D (10%) (). The anion-exchanged compounds 1A, 1B, and 1D displayed very less shift as compared to 1, while 1C and 1E are blue-shifted. The plausible rationale to the variation in luminescence intensities of the different anion-exchanged compounds is not very obvious, but the variation can be attributed to the various electrostatic/supramolecular interactions (π–π and hydrogen-bonding) of the anions with the framework walls and Hg­(II) center, depending upon their size, shape, and coordinating tendencies. 1H NMR spectra of sparingly soluble CP 1 and anion-exchanged compounds 1A–1E were recorded in DMSO-d 6 (Figure S17). However, it would be risky to use the data to propose either the existence or the disintegration of polymeric network in solution state. The chemical shift values related to the N–C H –N proton of benzimidazole moiety of the samples were not all the same. The spectral data could not be correlated to explain the nature of anion binding in any convincing manner.

elements.content: The molecule-based sensors (inorganic and organic) employed for anion exchange often suffer from low sensitivity, stability, and weak signals. However, CPs due to their excellent chemical stability, low contamination, and excellent recyclability are advantageous over small molecule-based sensors. Moreover, CPs have proven to be effective solid anion sensor materials, as their compositions and properties can be easily tuned by altering their components, a property that is elusive in molecular hosts. In addition, CPs are able to amplify the signal from a recognition event resulting in an amplification/quenching of fluorescence when compared to small molecule sensors. The reason behind this difference lies in the fact that upon guest-binding, in case of a small molecule, a single chromophore is affected leading to change in its fluorescence, whereas binding to a CP affects the fluorescence of an entire chain of macromolecular chromophores. Combining all these properties of CPs, the flexible framework, insolubility (both aqueous and nonaqueous medium), and high hydrolytic stability of CP 1 make it superior over molecule-based sensors for anion-exchange process. The presence of flexible linker L makes the coordination network more adaptive as well as responsive to anion exchange and triggering a manifold increase in the host–guest interactions, thereby leading to enhanced quenching signal.

Combining all these properties of CPs, the flexible framework, insolubility (both aqueous and nonaqueous medium), and high hydrolytic stability of CP 1 make it superior over molecule-based sensors for anion-exchange process. The presence of flexible linker L makes the coordination network more adaptive as well as responsive to anion exchange and triggering a manifold increase in the host-guest interactions, thereby leading to enhanced quenching signal.

elements.content: The aromatic rings of NACs are electron-deficient due to the presence of electron-withdrawing nitro (−NO2) groups, resulting into formation of effective charge-transfer complexes with electron-rich fluorophores leading to subsequent fluorescence quenching. CPs with high photoluminescent properties often exhibit excellent sensing performance, especially for the detection of electron-deficient nitro explosives. In addition, the presence of −OH/–NH2 groups in NACs provides opportunities for the formation of multiple supramolecular interactions between the host and guest molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Nitroaromatics Sensing

The aromatic rings of NACs are electron-deficient due to the presence of electron-withdrawing nitro (-NO2) groups, resulting into formation of effective charge-transfer complexes with electron-rich fluorophores leading to subsequent fluorescence quenching. CPs with high photoluminescent properties often exhibit excellent sensing performance, especially for the detection of electron-deficient nitro explosives. In addition, the presence of -OH/-NH2 groups in NACs provides opportunities for the formation of multiple supramolecular interactions between the host and guest molecules.

elements.content: However, so far employing Hg­(II) CPs for the detection of NACs is not explored, primarily due to the quenching of photoluminescence caused by Hg­(II) metal ion on account of heavy atom effect. Interestingly, complexation of L with Hg­(II) metal ion increases the luminescence intensity of CP 1 almost threefold making it highly luminescent material. Moreover, the selectivity feature of NACs detection can undergo manifold enhancement by incorporation of a recognition site within the coordination space. In CP 1 the presence of noncoordinating benzimidazole moiety can act as recognition site for the improvement of selectivity.

elements.content: To utilize CPs as sensory materials, it is of primary importance for them to display relatively strong emission intensity in the selected solvent. Thus, the fluorescent properties of 1 were investigated by dispersing a finely ground sample of 1 (0.5 mg) in various solvents (10 mL) and ultrasonicated for 20 min. The emission intensities of 1 show distinct solvent-dependent photoluminescence and followed the decreasing order: H2O, methanol, tetrahydrofuran (THF), phenol, aniline, dichloromethane (DCM), toluene, DMF, chlorobenzene, benzene, acetone, and nitrobenzene (Figure S26). Interestingly, 1 possesses the strongest emission in water and was selected as the detection medium to make the measurements more close to the environmental aqueous condition and understand the detection results merely from the changes of emission intensity. Such solvent-dependent fluorescent properties are meaningful in the sensing of solvents that are dangerous to human health and the environment.

elements.content: Framework of 1 was found to be highly stable in water as verified by powder XRD, which revealed no change even after boiling 1 in water for 24 h (Figure S27). Also, stability of CP 1 in water after 60 min of sonication was further verified by powder XRD (Figure S28). Encouraged by this, as well as excellent solid-state emission, application of 1 for the detection of nitro explosives in aqueous media was evaluated, which is highly desirable concerning the present scenario of social safety.

For NACs detection, a 10 mM DMF solution of each analyte was prepared and added incrementally to 3 mL stock solution of 1 in water, and changes in the fluorescence intensity were recorded. The quenching efficiencies were estimated using the equation: [(I 0 – I)/I 0]] × 100, with I 0 and I being the emission intensities of 1 before and after the addition of NAC, respectively. The descending order of quenching efficiencies is as follows (, a, and Figures S29–S39): TNP (80%), DNP (67%), 4-NP (40%), 4-NA (38%), 4-ANP (32%), 2-NP (27%), 2-NA (22%), 5-ANP (22%), 3-NP (17%), CDNB (17%), CNB (14%), and NAP (7%).

The gradual addition of TNP to 1 led to very efficient fluorescence quenching and reduced the fluorescence intensity of 1 to almost zero at a very low concentration of 20 μM (a), which can be accounted for by the electron-deficient nature of TNP due to three strong electron-withdrawing −NO2 groups. The quenching efficiency decreases upon decrease in the number of −NO2 groups from three to two (DNP) and subsequently to one (2-NP, 3-NP, and 4-NP) as compared to TNP. In addition to nitrophenols, the experiment with nitroanilines (2-NA and 4-NA), as well as amino-nitrophenols (4-ANP and 5-ANP), also showed less quenching as compared to TNP. However, nitrocompounds with electron-withdrawing groups (NAP, CNB, and DNB) exhibit poor fluorescence quenching (a). These results clearly suggest the highest selectivity of 1 toward TNP in all selected nitro explosives. A further systematic study also reveals that 1 shows different response in the presence of strong electron-donating (−OH and −NH2) and electron-withdrawing groups −COCH3 (moderate) and −Cl (weak), and this can be ascribed to the difference in their electron-withdrawing ability.

elements.content: The quenching efficiency in liquid media can be quantitatively analyzed by Stern–Volmer (SV) analysis following equation I 0/I = 1 + K sv[Q]. Here I 0 and I represent the initial fluorescence intensity of 1 in absence and presence of analyte, respectively, with molar concentration [Q], and K SV is the quenching constant (M–1). The higher K SV indicates higher efficiency of a sensor for a particular analyte leading to higher quenching efficiency.

elements.content: The SV plots of analytes exhibit slight linear uplift with their increasing concentration (b, , and Figures S29–S39), while in case of TNP, a deviation from linearity in the SV plot with upward rising behavior is observed with a high quenching constant (K SV ≈ 3.25 × 105 M–1; b). The enhancement in quenching upon increasing concentration leads to growth of nonlinear traits and can be accounted for: (i) dynamic quenching observed due to collision of TNP molecules into the channels of 1, and (ii) static quenching mechanism in ground state due to complex formation. The high quenching efficiency and K SV values demonstrate that 1 is able to detect TNP, over other nitro explosives, at a lower concentration with a limit of detection of 0.55 ppm (). In addition, CP 1 was found to be stable after the quenching of fluorescence by different NACs and was analyzed by the powder XRD pattern obtained after addition of NACs (Figure S40).

elements.content:
The extraordinary selectivity toward TNP sensing is usually assigned to the energy- and electron-transfer processes, as well as multiple interactions between the host framework and guest molecule.

The possible fluorescence quenching mechanism of 1 toward NACs can be proposed to be via photoinduced electron transfer (PET) between the electron-rich 1 and the electron-deficient NACs, which is a well-established quenching mechanism. Generally, the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of the electron-deficient NACs lies somewhere between the ground state (valence band, VB) and excited state (conduction band, CB) of extended CP framework. Therefore, upon photoinduced excitation, the excited electrons can then be transferred from the relatively high orbital energies of the CB of 1 to LUMO of NACs, leading to fluorescence quenching.

Generally, the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of the electron-deficient NACs lies somewhere between the ground state (valence band, VB) and excited state (conduction band, CB) of extended CP framework. Therefore, upon photoinduced excitation, the excited electrons can then be transferred from the relatively high orbital energies of the CB of 1 to LUMO of NACs, leading to fluorescence quenching.

elements.content: However, the nonlinear trait in the Stern–Volmer plot at higher concentration of TNP, as compared to the linear plot of other NACs, may also imply that another mechanism, in addition to PET, takes effect simultaneously, namely, fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET). It is observed for the systems exhibiting an overlap of absorption band of the NACs with the emission band of the CP, thereby leading to high fluorescence quenching. A considerable overlap of the absorption curve of TNP with the emission curve of 1 (Figure S41) clearly supports that an excited-state energy transfer mechanism operates between 1 and TNP.

A considerable overlap of the absorption curve of TNP with the emission curve of 1 (Figure S41) clearly supports that an excited-state energy transfer mechanism operates between 1 and TNP.

elements.content: In addition, the functional groups present within the framework, such as Lewis acidic or basic sites in the ligands, and/or open metal sites, further promote preferred analyte binding, either via chemical reaction or interaction (electrostatic and π-interactions), for selective recognition of desired analytes. The highly acidic TNP, with three −NO2 groups, is well-known to interact with Lewis basic sites present in CPs owing to its acidic phenolic proton. To probe the role of the pendant Lewis basic benzimidazole moiety present in 1 in the observed selectivity of TNP, fluorescence quenching experiments were performed with other −OH group-containing analytes NACs, which can interact with the basic sites of 1 including: DNP and NP. The fluorescence quenching performance correlates well with the acidity of the phenolic protons: TNP > DNP > NP. This trend supports the presence of a combination of π–π stacking along with electrostatic interaction between highly acidic −OH group of TNP and the pendant Lewis basic benzimidazole moiety leading to pronounced quenching effect, which is carried over long range owing to the energy transfer mechanism, thus leading to an amplified response.

elements.content: The recyclability and photostability of a sensor material is an important aspect to meet the requirements of real-life sensing applications. Subsequently, the reusability of 1 for sensing TNP was tested by recycling experiments. The emission intensity of 1 was first recorded in the presence of TNP at 20 μM concentration, and framework was regenerated after every cycle and reused by centrifuging the dispersed solution and washing several times with DMF until the centrifugate became colorless. After five cycles of repetition, almost 93% of the initial emission intensity was retained, and thus CP 1 showed excellent recyclability (). In addition, the excellent photostability of CP 1 is also revealed by this study as well as its powder XRD pattern (Figure S42), showing that it can be used for a significant number of sensing cycles as an efficient luminescent sensor.
elements.clean_text:
Recyclability and Photostability

The recyclability and photostability of a sensor material is an important aspect to meet the requirements of real-life sensing applications. Subsequently, the reusability of 1 for sensing TNP was tested by recycling experiments. The emission intensity of 1 was first recorded in the presence of TNP at 20 μM concentration, and framework was regenerated after every cycle and reused by centrifuging the dispersed solution and washing several times with DMF until the centrifugate became colorless. After five cycles of repetition, almost 93% of the initial emission intensity was retained, and thus CP 1 showed excellent recyclability (). In addition, the excellent photostability of CP 1 is also revealed by this study as well as its powder XRD pattern (Figure S42), showing that it can be used for a significant number of sensing cycles as an efficient luminescent sensor.

elements.content: In summary, we have synthesized a new highly fluorescent 1D double chain coordination network {[Hg­(L)2]·(ClO4)2} n (1) based on semirigid tridentate benzimidazole-based ligand, 1,3,5-tris­(1-benzimidazolylmethyl) benzene (L). The weakly held ClO4 – anions in the cavities of 1 can be exchanged in a reversible (complete anion exchange: NO3 – and BF4 –) and irreversible manner (partial anion exchange: OTf–, OTs–, and PF6 –) depending upon the nature of the anions forming promising anion-exchange materials. The anion exchange resulted in anion-triggered tunable luminescence by a turn-off process, which could be a useful method to monitor the anion exchange and can seek applications in the field of anion sensing/removal. 1 exhibits solvent-dependent fluorescence intensities, and strongest emission with high hydrolytic stability makes it suitable for the detection of electron-deficient nitro explosives in aqueous media. A turn off of the emission intensity of 1 after TNP detection operates due to a synergetic effect of electron- and energy-transfer mechanisms as well as the interaction between Lewis basic pendant bezimidazole moiety, acting as a recognition site, thereby enabling the reversible uptake/release of TNP with excellent regeneration and recycling. To our best knowledge, 1 is the first example of a Hg­(II)-based fluorescent CP having good sensitivity for detecting even small amount of TNP (0.55 ppm) and discriminating nitrophenol (2-, 3- and 4-NP) and nitroaniline (2-NA and 4-NA) isomers efficiently through fluorescence sensing. Thus, an extrinsic dynamic nature of the cationic framework 1 is observed due to the differential multistimuli-responsive behavior for anions, solvents, and NACs, making CP 1 a “smart” material showing multifunctional behavior and can be used as a sensor. The strategy adopted herein can be further extended and improved to obtain other fluorescent Hg­(II)-based CPs providing even better sensors for anions and explosives for real-time monitoring.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have synthesized a new highly fluorescent 1D double chain coordination network {[Hg(L)2]⋅(ClO4)2} n  (1) based on semirigid tridentate benzimidazole-based ligand, 1,3,5-tris(1-benzimidazolylmethyl) benzene (L). The weakly held ClO4 - anions in the cavities of 1 can be exchanged in a reversible (complete anion exchange: NO3 - and BF4 -) and irreversible manner (partial anion exchange: OTf-, OTs-, and PF6 -) depending upon the nature of the anions forming promising anion-exchange materials. The anion exchange resulted in anion-triggered tunable luminescence by a turn-off process, which could be a useful method to monitor the anion exchange and can seek applications in the field of anion sensing/removal. 1 exhibits solvent-dependent fluorescence intensities, and strongest emission with high hydrolytic stability makes it suitable for the detection of electron-deficient nitro explosives in aqueous media. A turn off of the emission intensity of 1 after TNP detection operates due to a synergetic effect of electron- and energy-transfer mechanisms as well as the interaction between Lewis basic pendant bezimidazole moiety, acting as a recognition site, thereby enabling the reversible uptake/release of TNP with excellent regeneration and recycling. To our best knowledge, 1 is the first example of a Hg(II)-based fluorescent CP having good sensitivity for detecting even small amount of TNP (0.55 ppm) and discriminating nitrophenol (2-, 3- and 4-NP) and nitroaniline (2-NA and 4-NA) isomers efficiently through fluorescence sensing. Thus, an extrinsic dynamic nature of the cationic framework 1 is observed due to the differential multistimuli-responsive behavior for anions, solvents, and NACs, making CP 1 a "smart" material showing multifunctional behavior and can be used as a sensor. The strategy adopted herein can be further extended and improved to obtain other fluorescent Hg(II)-based CPs providing even better sensors for anions and explosives for real-time monitoring.

The ligand was synthesized according to literature procedure.

Synthesis {[Hg­(L)<sub>2</sub>]·(ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>}<sub>n</sub>

Mercury­(II) perchlorate trihydrate (11.3 mg, 0.025 mmol) and L (23.42 mg, 0.05 mmol) were dissolved in 0.5 mL of DMSO. The solution was heated at 70 °C for 12 h and left for one week at room temperature to afford X-ray quality colorless block crystals. Yield 19.5 mg, 60%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3434 (br), 3118 (br), 1607 (w), 1518 (m), 1460 (w), 1386 (w), 1263 (w), 1198 (m), 1091 (vs), 1002 (m), 943 (w), 875­(w), 750 (s), 620 (m), 540 (w). Anal. Calcd (%) for C60H48Cl2HgN12O8: C, 53.92; H, 3.62; N, 12.58. Found: C, 53.66; H, 3.32; N, 12.98.

cln_elements.content: To confirm the sample purity, powder XRD was performed for 1, which showed correlation between the simulated and experimental spectra, thereby confirming the phase purity of 1 at room temperature (Figure S5). The thermal stability of the same was studied using TGA, and the TGA profile indicated that it is thermally stable up to 245 °C, thereafter showing a sudden weight loss, leaving a residual weight of 23% (Figure S6).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction and Thermogravimetric Analysis

To confirm the sample purity, powder XRD was performed for 1, which showed correlation between the simulated and experimental spectra, thereby confirming the phase purity of 1 at room temperature (Figure S5). The thermal stability of the same was studied using TGA, and the TGA profile indicated that it is thermally stable up to 245 °C, thereafter showing a sudden weight loss, leaving a residual weight of 23% (Figure S6).
